title: A Solution to the Faint-Sun Paradox Reveals a Narrow Window for Life
content: In the early solar system, a close-orbiting moon would have contorted Earth’s interior, heating it from within.

title: A Solution to the Faint-Sun Paradox Reveals a Narrow Window for Life
content: James O’Brien for Quanta Magazine

content: Our sun is getting brighter. If you could travel back in time to the dawn of the solar system 4.5 billion years ago, you’d find a star that was about 30% dimmer than it is now. Over the subsequent eons, it has shone more and more brilliantly — a function of the nuclear fusion process that takes place in the cores of stars like our own — and it will continue to do so until the end of its life, roughly 5 billion years from now.

content: And yet it did. We know that our planet had liquid water on its surface as early as 4.4 billion years ago, and maybe even earlier, as water vapor condensed out of the atmosphere. Single-celled life seems to have sprung up shortly thereafter. And both the planet’s water and its life have persisted — despite a few close calls — to concoct the relative oasis we inhabit today.

content: The faint young sun paradox, as it’s known, has vexed scientists for decades. But recent work has led many researchers to think that we now have a solid hold on the problem. Old ideas have been refined, while new ideas — including one involving an unnervingly close moon that sculpted tidal waves the size of skyscrapers — have helped to fill the few remaining gaps in our understanding.
